entry.title: PLM Tech Uncovered: SAP Integrated Product Development Update 09/2025
entry.content:
Hello and welcome to the September 2025 edition of this blog series! I'm happy to share the newest features of SAP Integrated Product Development with you, so let's get started right away:

General
Navigate to apps in SAP Integrated Product Development using Joule
You can navigate to all apps in SAP Integrated Product Development by asking Joule to open them. Users can open the requested apps using the button in Joule‚Äôs response, provided they have authorization to access them.

Collaboration
Use Joule to generate summaries for documents
You can use Joule to generate summaries for documents uploaded in the My Collaborations app.

Specification Management
Load data from external systems
Specification Management offers a hybrid solution for data integration with SAP S/4HANA systems. With the help of this functionality, you can load specification object content from an SAP S/4HANA specification to a SAP Integrated Product Development specification.
Default inheritance template for creating specifications
You can select a default inheritance template per specification type in the Specification Types app. This default template is then used to create specifications when you choose ‚ÄúCreate with Inheritance‚Äù in the Manage Specifications app.
Clear phrase value from attribute fields to empty state
If you enter a phrase value for a property, you can now clear the value.

Visualization
Auto detection of hotspots in P&ID drawings
You can automatically generate hotspots from 2D Drawings that contain piping and instrumentation diagram.

üîî To stay informed until the next update you can:
‚úèÔ∏è  Subscribe to the What‚Äôs New Viewer on SAP Integrated Product Development Help Portal https://url.sap/5nbm4a
üîóJoin our LinkedIn group SAP Solutions for PLM https://www.linkedin.com/groups/9257139/
üåê  Visit us at www.sap.com/IPD

üì¢üí° By the way, do you know how to provide feedback for SAP Integrated Product Development?
‚û°Ô∏è  Watch this video to find out how and send your feedback directly from the application. We always look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 IR/GR 8% threshold, invoice/credit posting
entry.content:
Hi Tom,

I am not aware of such system control that allows you to set acceptable deviation percentage between GRPO and AP Invoice. I believe this is a custom setup, most likely done via stored procedure control where amount on AP invoice is compared to amount of it's base GRPO document.

You should be able to change this, but it might be best to discuss it with your partner who implemented this, they should know the reason behind it.

In general, you absolutely can add AP invoice with amount different than its base GRPO. If this is Item type document and the goods are received to the warehouse via GRPO, you can add AP invoice which will automatically recalculate the value of received goods. Should go like this:

1. Purchase order for 800‚Ç¨.

2. GRPO for 800‚Ç¨ (usually just copied from PO, warehouse operators don't usually deal with price differences)

3. AP Invoice for 2400‚Ç¨

3a. If the goods are still in warehouse when you create AP Invoice, value will be changed to the one on AP invoice (in your case value will increase by 1600‚Ç¨)

3b. If the goods are not available anymore (sold or issued to production), value will not be changed but the difference will be posted to separate price difference account.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud / Problem with the Migration of Cont...
entry.content:
UPDATE: After some research we found a solution to this problem. The first app you need is "Import Master Data - BP Relationships" (F6552A). There you can download example files that can be used for the import. Within the file "BREL_Simple_Create" you can add the two business partners that you want to establish the relationship for. You also need to add the type of relationship, in my case "BUR001" for the contact person relationship. After that its just a simple upload.
In the app "Manage Mass Creation Processes - BP Relationships (Version 2)" (F6560A) you can now create a process based on this import and validate the imported data and finaly import it into the system.

entry.title: Re: aATP - Confirmation Strategies
entry.content: Hi Adam, are you using just BOP or also aATP ABC (Alternative Based Confirmation). If you have HANA 2023 FPS 03 (and perhaps lower) then you could get the system to confirm from origination plant (up to available quantity) and then from central DC for the rest, including leaving the open qty (unconfirmed qty, if any) on the central DC. This uses a Main Item/Sub-Item construct. We are implementing currently, so still learning a little. Stephan

entry.title: How to handle the auto. creation of costing views in CK11N/CK40N for materials with price control V?
entry.content:
Hi everybody,

when we run calculations with ck40n materials with price control V are also selected. 
If these materials do not have a costing view in the master data, the selection step already creates a costing view. 
My opinion is that this is counterintuitive, as these materials are priced based on pruchase orders / goods receipts / invoices.

How can I prevent that the costing view is created?
Isn't there a general mechanism that excludes materials with price control v from the selection in a calculation run?

SAP S/4HANA 107
Thanks

Alex

entry.title: A Hitchhiker's Guide to SAP Fiori User Experience and its Technologies ‚Äì 2025 edition
entry.content:
I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve heard of SAP Fiori, the design system for all SAP products. SAP Fiori covers the design itself, the SAP Fiori applications delivered by SAP, but also technologies and tools to run those apps, to extend standard SAP apps or even to develop your own custom apps.

  • Are you looking for a high-level understanding of SAP Fiori and its technologies and tools?
  • Would you like to get an overview to see how all of this fits together?
  • Do you know which role SAP Build plays?
  • You have an ABAP / on-prem background and want to learn about how SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) / cloud is used for SAP Fiori?
  • Do you want to leverage entry points for your own practical learning, e.g. recommended tutorials?

Look no further. This 2-part webinar helps and provides entry points for your hands-on learning.

Agenda Part 1

SAP Fiori is the User Experience of SAP Business Suite that changes the way you work. In this overview you‚Äôll get a first understanding of SAP Fiori: The SAP Fiori design system and how it is realized with the related UI technologies and tools, for business users, key users, and developers. This part covers the main environments like SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform. The overview extends to the actual productive usage of SAP Fiori business applications via an SAP Fiori launchpad, and the essential UI frameworks.

  • The SAP Fiori Design system
  • An overview of Technologies and Tools for SAP Fiori
  • The entry point to SAP Fiori: SAP Build Work Zone
  • The strategic UI frameworks SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements

Agenda Part 2

In the second part we‚Äôll cover SAP Build for AI‚Äìbased application development and, of course, look at ABAP development tools. This leads us to the important scenario of extensibility and how you can easily add custom extension to standard SAP apps. Mobile technologies and a Q&A section close the second part.

  • The SAP Build development environment and ABAP Development Tools in Eclipse
  • Extending standard SAP applications with Clean Core principles
  • Technologies for a mobile experience

Who Should Attend?

This overview session is for everyone, from executives to software developers. It is a complete run-through of SAPs user experience technologies, ranging from end user personalization to developer tools, from creating an initial project to productively using an app. This content is especially useful if you have an ABAP background and need a sound overview understanding of SAP Fiori and its tools and technologies. The webinar has a focus on providing the full picture and entry points into further learnings.

üëâ Join me for this 2-part webinar, live on October 28. and 30., 17:00 ‚Äì 18:00 CET on YouTube Part 1 and Part 2.

entry.title: üöÄ SAP BTP Weekly: ¬øEstamos listos para dejar que la IA ejecute nuestros procesos?
entry.content:
1. Joule Studio y agentes de IA en procesos SAP

SAP anunci√≥ que Joule Studio ser√° generalmente disponible en junio de 2025 como entorno integrado en SAP Build para construir habilidades (skills) y agentes de IA que ejecutan workflows complejos. Los desarrolladores podr√°n dise√±ar agentes que act√∫en con contexto de negocio en procesos, no solo tareas puntuales. La Integration Suite sumar√° capacidades de recomendaci√≥n autom√°tica y predicci√≥n de anomal√≠as en API calls. Esto reduce c√≥digo repetitivo y acelera la automatizaci√≥n contextual. Pero la gobernanza ser√° clave para evitar ‚Äúcajas negras‚Äù.

Ventajas :

 

  • Acelera el desarrollo de procesos inteligentes.
  • Mejora la eficiencia operativa con agentes en tiempo real.
  • Incrementa la trazabilidad y capacidad de respuesta.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øDejar√≠as que un agente aut√≥nomo ejecute decisiones operativas en tu organizaci√≥n?

2. SAP Build Process Automation con IA generativa

SAP Build Process Automation incorpora IA generativa para que usuarios de negocio dise√±en flujos sin necesidad de c√≥digo. Un CFO o analista puede describir un proceso en lenguaje natural y el sistema genera el flujo base. Arquitectos y desarrolladores ajustan la l√≥gica para robustecerlo. Esto acelera la entrega de valor en procesos clave. El reto ser√° equilibrar agilidad con gobernanza y control.

Ventajas :

 

  • Democratiza la automatizaci√≥n para √°reas de negocio.
  • Reduce tiempos de entrega de procesos digitales.
  • Fomenta colaboraci√≥n entre negocio y tecnolog√≠a.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øConfiar√≠as en que √°reas de negocio creen flujos cr√≠ticos con IA generativa?

3. SAP Business Network sobre SAP BTP

La red de colaboraci√≥n SAP Business Network se integra m√°s fuerte a BTP. Esto habilita trazabilidad, compliance e IA nativos en la red. Los procesos con proveedores y compradores ganan sincron√≠a. Pero aumenta la complejidad de gobernanza y onboarding de socios. La adopci√≥n depende tambi√©n de la madurez de cada partner.

Ventajas :

 

  • Mayor transparencia en la cadena de suministro.
  • Procesos m√°s √°giles entre m√∫ltiples organizaciones.
  • Cumplimiento normativo m√°s f√°cil de demostrar.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øExtender√≠as procesos cr√≠ticos a tu red de socios usando BTP?

4. Innovaciones de AI en SAP Integration Suite

Integration Suite ahora sugiere mapas de integraci√≥n y detecta conflictos autom√°ticamente. Se anuncia un ‚Äúadaptador AI‚Äù para conectar LLM externos. Esto acelera los ciclos de integraci√≥n con recomendaciones en tiempo real. Permite prever consumos de API y anticipar cuellos de botella. Los equipos deber√°n validar sugerencias de la IA para asegurar calidad.

Ventajas :

 

  • Reduce tiempos de desarrollo y testing.
  • Anticipa problemas antes de que impacten la operaci√≥n.
  • Facilita integraciones complejas con IA como copiloto.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øConfiar√≠as en una IA para dise√±ar mapas de integraci√≥n productivos?

5. Estrategia ‚ÄúClean Core + extensibilidad con BTP‚Äù

La idea central es mantener el core SAP est√°ndar y mover extensiones a BTP. Esto evita deuda t√©cnica y facilita upgrades en el core. Implica redise√±ar l√≠mites entre procesos est√°ndar y diferenciadores. Las extensiones requieren su propia gobernanza y testing. Es un cambio cultural y t√©cnico importante.

Ventajas :

 

  • Facilita actualizaciones del core.
  • Permite innovar sin comprometer estabilidad.
  • Reduce costos de mantenimiento a largo plazo.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øTu empresa ya avanza hacia un core limpio o a√∫n lo ves lejano?

6. Gobernanza de datos en entornos BTP h√≠bridos

La mezcla de datos SAP y no SAP en BTP exige un modelo de gobierno s√≥lido. Es clave definir roles, propiedad y calidad del dato maestro. La replicaci√≥n entre entornos puede generar inconsistencias si no se dise√±a bien. Se deben cumplir regulaciones locales y globales de privacidad. El lineage del dato ser√° un diferenciador en auditor√≠as.

Ventajas :

 

  • Mayor confianza en reportes y decisiones.
  • Cumplimiento m√°s sencillo ante auditor√≠as.
  • Reducci√≥n de duplicaciones e inconsistencias.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øPrefer√≠s un modelo √∫nico de datos o m√∫ltiples vistas seg√∫n √°rea de negocio?

7. Adopci√≥n de BTP en industrias reguladas

Industrias reguladas exigen trazabilidad, certificaciones y seguridad extrema. SAP NS2 propone un marco espec√≠fico para implementar BTP en estos entornos. Esto incluye segregaci√≥n de ambientes y auditor√≠a constante. El cumplimiento requiere alineaci√≥n entre IT, compliance y negocio. No todas las regulaciones est√°n actualizadas al modelo cloud.

Ventajas :

 

  • Confianza de auditores y entes reguladores.
  • Menor riesgo legal y reputacional.
  • Innovaci√≥n cloud en sectores tradicionalmente r√≠gidos.

 

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

¬øUsar√≠as BTP en procesos cr√≠ticos de tu industria regulada o solo para innovaci√≥n?

entry.title: (RAP/Fiori) Currency Annotation/Formatting Not Applied for Action with Parameters in Fiori UI
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm encountering a specific issue where a currency field in a Fiori Elements UI is not being formatted correctly, but only when it's part of a parameter dialog for an parameter action.

The Problem:

I have an action that requires parameters, including an Amount and a Currency Code. In my abstract CDS view, I've set up the standard annotations to link the amount field to its corresponding currency code field, like this:




On the UI, when the action dialog opens, the 'Amount' field should automatically adjust its display and validation based on the selected currency. For instance, it should enforce two decimal places for currencies like USD or EUR, and zero for currencies like JPY or KRW.

The key issue is the lack of decimal place conversion. For example, if the currency is set to 'USD', entering a value of 100 is not automatically interpreted or displayed as 100.00. The UI treats it as a simple number, failing to apply the correct currency-specific precision.

This same annotation works perfectly for fields on our main List Report and Object Pages, but it seems to fail specifically within the context of an action's parameter dialog. I've already confirmed that both the amount and currency values are correctly passed in the OData payload.

Has anyone else faced this issue? Is there a known limitation or a different approach required for applying currency annotations to action parameters?

Any help or insight would be greatly appreciated.



Dear

@Andre_Fischer  
@MioYasutake 

I was wondering if you might have come across this specific behavior before. My apologies for the direct mention, but any insight you could provide would be incredibly helpful.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Stakeholderanalyse in SAP-Projekten: Praxiserprobte Methoden und wertvolle Erfahrungen
entry.content:
Die September-Ausgabe der SAP Kaffee Ecke widmete sich einem zentralen Erfolgsfaktor f√ºr SAP-Transformationen: der systematischen Stakeholderanalyse. Holly Hammerton, Leiterin des Digital Change and Adoption Teams bei SAP und erfahrene Psychologin, teilte ihre praktischen Erfahrungen und bew√§hrten Methoden mit den Teilnehmenden.Stakeholderanalyse als Erfolgsfaktor verstehen

Die Eingangsbefragung zeigte bereits die Relevanz des Themas: √úber 60 Prozent der Teilnehmenden verf√ºgten √ºber Erfahrungen mit Stakeholderanalysen. In der gemeinsamen Wortwolke zur Frage, welche Themen oder Aspekte die Teilnehmenden typischerweise in einer Stakeholderanalyse analysieren, kristallisierten sich schnell die wichtigsten Aspekte heraus - von Einfluss und Motivation √ºber Rollen und Verantwortlichkeiten bis hin zu Transformationszielen und Change-Erfahrungen.

Holly er√∂ffnete ihre Pr√§sentation mit einer lehrreichen Anekdote aus ihrer fr√ºhen Beraterzeit. In einem Projekt hatte sie sich zu stark auf die Einsch√§tzung der Projektleitung verlassen und dabei einen hierarchisch scheinbar unbedeutsamen, aber faktisch sehr einflussreichen Bereichsleiter √ºbersehen. Dieser verz√∂gerte das Projekt daraufhin erheblich, da der Vorstand vollst√§ndig auf seine Expertise vertraute. "Wie h√§tten wir das vermeiden k√∂nnen? Indem ich eine ordentliche Stakeholderanalyse durchgef√ºhrt h√§tte - und zwar nicht nur aus Perspektive der Projektleitung", res√ºmierte sie.

WIESO Stakeholderanalysen in SAP-Transformationen entscheidend sind

Stakeholder in SAP-Transformationen sind zahlreich und sehr unterschiedlich. Wenn Change Manager sie verstehen, k√∂nnen sie Kommunikation gezielt steuern und Risiken reduzieren. Oft scheitern Projekte daran, dass Entscheidungstr√§ger nicht den n√∂tigen R√ºckhalt geben - beispielsweise bei der Ressourcenfreigabe. Die Stakeholderanalyse hilft dabei, genau diese Personen zu identifizieren, die Unterst√ºtzung und Sponsorship sichern k√∂nnen.

Dar√ºber hinaus erm√∂glicht sie eine passgenaue Planung von Kommunikation und Ma√ünahmen. "Wen habe ich vor mir und welche Wege nutze ich, um mit ihnen zu kommunizieren? Was brauchen diese Stakeholdergruppen √ºberhaupt an Informationen und zu welchem Zeitpunkt?", fasste Holly die zentralen Fragen zusammen. Widerst√§nde werden fr√ºh sichtbar durch die Analyse der Stakeholder-Einstellungen zum Projekt. Gleichzeitig k√∂nnen Multiplikatoren gezielt erkannt und genutzt werden. Die regelm√§√üige √úberpr√ºfung der Ver√§nderungsbereitschaft und Wirksamkeit von Ma√ünahmen zeigt den Return on Investment der Stakeholderanalyse auf.

WIE kann man Stakeholderanalysen durchf√ºhren

Hollys klare Empfehlung lautet: fr√ºh beginnen und kontinuierlich aktualisieren. In SAP Projekten empfiehlt sie ein systematisches Vorgehen entlang der SAP Activate Methodik:

Bereits in der Prepare-Phase sollten erste Stakeholderanalysen durchgef√ºhrt werden, da hier schon Entscheidungstr√§ger identifizierbar sind - auch wenn Enduser in dieser Phase noch nicht immer unbedingt bekannt sind. Analyse und Management der Stakeholder greifen dabei iterativ Hand in Hand.

Das systematische Vorgehen umfasst mehrere Schritte: Die Identifikation erfasst direkt und indirekt betroffene Stakeholder. Die Analyse erfolgt zun√§chst auf Gruppenebene durch B√ºndelung nach Bereichen oder Regionen, dann auf Individualebene f√ºr Influencer in ihren Bereichen oder zuk√ºnftige Key User. Anschlie√üend werden Ma√ünahmen zum Stakeholder-Engagement abgeleitet und durchgef√ºhrt.

Regelm√§√üige Updates der Stakeholderanalyse - entweder zur n√§chsten Projektphase, zu wichtigen Projektmeilensteinen oder zu festen Zeitintervallen wie zum Beispiel alle drei Monate - stellen die Aktualit√§t sicher. "Rinse and repeat" beschreibt den kontinuierlich wiederholten Prozess bis zum Transformationserfolg umgangssprachlich.

Bew√§hrte Tools f√ºr die praktische Umsetzung

Die Vierfeldertafel als Herzst√ºck

Die klassische Vierfeldertafel bildet das Herzst√ºck der Stakeholderanalyse. Sie kategorisiert Stakeholder nach ihrem Einfluss auf das Projekt (Level of influence on project success) und ihrer Einstellung dazu (Attitude towards project). Die vier Kategorien erfordern unterschiedliche Engagement-Strategien, im Folgenden grob umschrieben:

Opponents (hoher Einfluss, negative Einstellung) erfordern erhebliche Investitionen in gezielte Aktivit√§ten. Erste Priorit√§t ist es, ihre Einstellung zum Projekt zu √§ndern. Alternativ sollte versucht werden, ihren Einfluss auf den Projekterfolg zu reduzieren.

Promoters (hoher Einfluss, positive Einstellung) werden durch gezielte Aktionen in ihrer positiven Haltung best√§rkt. Ihr Einfluss wird genutzt, um andere f√ºr das Projekt zu gewinnen, und sie werden als offizielle Sponsoren oder Multiplikatoren integriert.

Skeptics (geringer Einfluss, negative Einstellung) erhalten ausreichend Zeit und Information, um informiert zu bleiben. Besonders die Benefits des Projekts werden kommuniziert, und sie werden im Blick behalten.

Supporters (geringer Einfluss, positive Einstellung) werden ermutigt, ihren Einfluss auf das Projekt zu erh√∂hen, um sie auf das "Promoters"-Level zu bringen. Ihre positive Einstellung wird in ihrem jeweiligen Einflussbereich genutzt, und sie k√∂nnen beispielsweise gut zu Power Usern gemacht werden.

Die Stakeholder-Engagement-Aktivit√§ten umfassen meist verschiedene Formen von Kommunikation, Training & Enablement sowie Performance Management.

Dar√ºber hinaus stellte Holly eine Stakeholder Analyse auf individueller Ebene vor: Eine aggregierte Sicht auf die verschiedenen Stakeholder, z. B. ‚ÄûBusiness‚Äú vs. ‚ÄûIT‚Äú k√∂nnen helfen, zus√§tzliche Erkenntnisse zu gewinnen.

Kraftfeldanalyse f√ºr tieferes Verst√§ndnis

Erg√§nzend empfiehlt Holly die Kraftfeldanalyse nach Kurt Lewin, um treibende und hemmende Kr√§fte zu verstehen, die auf individuelle Stakeholder wirken. Diese Methode ist f√ºr wichtige Stakeholder und Stakeholder-Gruppen sinnvoll, da Widerst√§nde viele Hintergr√ºnde haben. Das Verstehen erm√∂glicht einem die Formulierung einer individuellen Strategie f√ºr den Umgang diesen Personen gegen√ºber.

Holly betonte dabei die Notwendigkeit der absoluten Vertraulichkeit aller solcher Bewertungen, da diese Art von Bewertungen in den falschen H√§nden verst√§ndlicherweise starke Emotionen und Reaktionen ausl√∂sen k√∂nnten.

Strukturierte Dokumentation auf Gruppenebene

Holly stellte eine praktische Excel-Vorlage f√ºr die Stakeholder-Analyse auf Gruppenebene vor. Diese kombiniert eine High-Level Impact-Analyse mit der eigentlichen Stakeholder-Analyse. Die Vorlage erfasst systematisch:

  • Stakeholder-Gruppe,
  • Standort,
  • Anzahl der Mitarbeiter,
  • Namen von Schl√ºsselpersonen,
  • bevorzugte Kommunikationskan√§le und zus√§tzliche Kommentare

High Level Impact-Analyse:

  • Auswirkungen der Ver√§nderung auf die Stakeholder-Gruppe
  • erwartete Reaktionen

Stakeholder-Analyse:

  • F√§higkeit, das Projekt zu beeinflussen
  • Einstellung zum Projekt

Diese strukturierte Herangehensweise erm√∂glicht es, sowohl den Change Impact als auch die Stakeholder-Dynamiken systematisch zu erfassen und daraus gezielte Ma√ünahmen abzuleiten.

WAS mache ich mit den Ergebnissen einer Stakeholderanalyse? Zielgerichtete Ma√ünahmen f√ºr jeden Stakeholder-Typ

Aus der Analyse folgen spezifische Handlungsempfehlungen f√ºr jeden Stakeholder-Typ. Bei Opponents wird versucht, sie zu Promotors zu machen oder wenigstens die negative Wahrnehmung zu reduzieren. Promoters werden so beibehalten und als Promotoren genutzt. Skeptics werden informiert gehalten, w√§hrend Supporters eingebunden und zu Change Champions, Support Speakern, Trainern oder Key Usern gemacht werden.

Besonders wertvoll ist Hollys Hinweis, Stakeholder untereinander wirken zu lassen: "Den Programmleiter zum Au√üenminister machen und den Rest der Firma von unserem Programm √ºberzeugen.", wie sie es ausdr√ºckte.

Praktische Take-aways f√ºr den Projektalltag

Holly fasste ihre Erkenntnisse in f√ºnf zentralen Take-aways zusammen:

  • Augen auf f√ºr indirekt betroffene Stakeholder und das systemische Umfeld: Nicht nur die offensichtlich Betroffenen ber√ºcksichtigen, sondern auch das weitere Umfeld im Blick behalten.
  • Ergebnisse explizit vertraulich behandeln: Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist hochsensibel und darf nur mit den relevanten Personen geteilt werden.
  • Ma√ünahmen an die konkrete Projektsituation anpassen: Politik, Kultur und Organisation des Unternehmens m√ºssen bei allen Aktivit√§ten ber√ºcksichtigt werden.
  • Stakeholder untereinander nutzen: Nicht nur direkte Beeinflussung planen, sondern auch den Einfluss von Stakeholdern untereinander strategisch einsetzen.
  • √úberarbeitung regelm√§√üig einplanen: Die Stakeholder-Analyse und Engagement-Aktivit√§ten m√ºssen zu festen Zeitpunkten aktiv √ºberarbeitet werden, da sich Gegebenheiten kontinuierlich √§ndern.

Im Anschluss an den Impuls starteten wir die Diskussion mit den Teilnehmenden. Die lebhafte Diskussionsrunde brachte typische Projektherausforderungen zur Sprache.

Bei wiederholten Go-Live-Verschiebungen wenn Vertrauensverlust wegen mangelnder Verbindlichkeit entsteht, empfiehlt Holly zun√§chst zu pr√ºfen, ob von der Projektleitung √ºberhaupt Ma√ünahmen bestimmt werden, damit der n√§chste Go-Live-Termin gehalten werden kann.

Als L√∂sung setzt sie auf Ehrlichkeit: Gr√ºnde f√ºr die Verschiebung kommunizieren und aufzeigen, welche Ma√ünahmen ergriffen werden, um den n√§chsten Termin zu halten - beispielsweise Quality Gates. Gleichzeitig sollten Quick Wins und Meilensteine geteilt werden, die bereits erreicht wurden. Aktivit√§ten zur Vorbereitung wie Videos, Testimonials und positive Vibes k√∂nnen helfen. Eine erneute Stakeholderanalyse kann zus√§tzlich sinnvoll sein.

F√ºr die Aufwandssch√§tzung f√ºr eine ordentliche Stakeholder Analyse nannte sie im Schnitt ca. 5-10 Arbeitstage, abh√§ngig von der Projektgr√∂√üe. Auf Seiten der Counterparts sollten ein paar Stunden mit der Projektleitung blockiert und Nachfolgetermine f√ºr Ma√ünahmen eingeplant werden.

Bei der Frage "Mit wem die Analyse durchf√ºhren?" zur Vermeidung von subjektiven Verzerrungen empfiehlt sie als erste Anlaufstelle immer die Projektleitung und OCM-Counterpart beim Unternehmen. "Alte Hasen" im Unternehmen k√∂nnen einen ersten, wenn auch subjektiven Blick geben. Einige Alteingesessene sollten vorsichtig und diplomatisch befragt werden, wobei Vertraulichkeit oberste Priorit√§t hat.

KI-Unterst√ºtzung bei Stakeholder Analysen: Befragungen k√∂nnen mit KI ausgewertet werden, wobei Befragungen anonym durchgef√ºhrt werden sollten. Holly betonte dabei aber Datenschutzaspekte.

Bei der Frage, wieviele Informationen man wem mitgibt, gilt ihr Grundsatz: "Je emotionaler die Nachricht, desto direkter." Gerade wichtige Manager sollten einzeln abgeholt oder in einem Kick-off zusammengebracht werden. Solche Events k√∂nnen etwas locker gestaltet werden, damit die Emotionen positiv beeinflusst werden.

Zentrale Erkenntnisse f√ºr die Praxis

Die Kaffee Ecke verdeutlichte: Erfolgreiche SAP-Transformationen entstehen nicht durch perfekte Technik allein, sondern durch das systematische Verstehen und Einbinden aller relevanten Stakeholder. Hollys praxiserprobte Methoden und strukturierte Vorlagen bieten daf√ºr eine solide Grundlage, die sich in verschiedenen Projektgr√∂√üen und -kontexten bew√§hrt hat.

Besonders wertvoll waren ihre Hinweise zur vertraulichen Handhabung der Analyseergebnisse und die Betonung, dass Stakeholder-Management ein kontinuierlicher, iterativer Prozess ist, der regelm√§√üige Aufmerksamkeit und Anpassung erfordert.

 

Weiterf√ºhrende Informationen:

- Informationen zur Kaffee-Ecken-Reihe: [go4.events.sap.com](https://go4.events.sap.com/eur-change-training-kaffee-ecke/de_de/home.html)- N√§chste Session: Case Study zu Erfolgsfaktoren einer S/4HANA-Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials

- Informationen zu OCM Services der SAP https://www.sap.com/germany/cmp/oth/de-organizational-change-management/index.html

entry.title: Shipment cost: One truck, multiple stops
entry.content:
Dear All,

I have a requirement to allocate shipment cost for a group of shipments in one truck.  So for example, I have 2 deliveries for 2 different customers, 2 different shipments linked to those deliveries and one truck.  In all cases, the truck will have 2 shipments loaded. I have 2 stops with an extra charge for this, possibly 3 stops in the future. I want to know how I can track what deliveries/shipments are on that truck and drive my shipment cost calculation per shipment based on the number of drops and number of pallets . I have SAP S/4 HANA and basic LE-TRA. I dont have TM enabled and no handling units.

Could you please provide any guidance how to implement this?

Many thanks

entry.title: Vibe Coding with MCP Servers & SAP AI Core: Toward "Coding by Conversation"
entry.content:
Over the past few months, I‚Äôve explored vibe coding ‚Äî a workflow where you prompt the AI, it generates code, and you iterate. Fast and interactive, yes ‚Äî but in enterprise projects, context and governance are critical. Without them, hallucinations and mismatched code structures quickly emerge.

This is where MCP servers (Model Context Protocol) and SAP AI Core become essential. Tools like fiori server and cap server allow AI assistants to understand your CDS models, Fiori metadata, and application structure ‚Äî enabling contextual, reliable code generation.

In this blog, we‚Äôll explore the architecture, practical usage, and enterprise best practices that make AI-assisted coding robust and production-ready.

What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding is a transformative approach to software development ‚Äî essentially, coding by conversation.

  • You describe requirements in natural language.
  • The AI assistant interprets your intent and proposes code patches, scaffolding, or tests.
  • You review, refine, and approve the generated output.

The power of vibe coding lies in freeing developers from repetitive boilerplate tasks, allowing them to focus on high-value work like architecture, user experience, and business logic.

SAP‚Äôs reference architecture for vibe coding with Cline + SAP AI Core demonstrates how AI-assisted development can be safe, repeatable, and fully aligned with enterprise standards ‚Äî turning AI from a helper into a structured development partner.

Core Principles from the SAP Architecture

From the reference architecture, five principles stand out:

  1. Prompt-Driven Development ‚Äì Express features in natural language, and let the system automatically generate the initial scaffolding.
  2. Context Engineering ‚Äì Supply LLMs with only the necessary structural context, such as APIs, CDS models, or MCP metadata.
  3. AI-Assisted Test-First Approach ‚Äì Begin by generating tests, then guide the AI to produce code that fulfills those requirements.
  4. Human-in-the-Loop Governance ‚Äì Developers retain responsibility for ensuring compliance, performance, and security.

Introducing MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) acts as the bridge between your project and the AI assistant.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is designed to act as a powerful bridge between your project and the AI assistant, ensuring that development is not just driven by prompts but also grounded in real project context. Instead of leaving the AI to guess or hallucinate about how your application is structured, MCP Servers provide it with a deep, contextual understanding of your project.

They expose key elements such as metadata, annotations, models, services, entities, relationships, and queries. This allows the AI to reason intelligently about your project‚Äôs architecture, whether it‚Äôs related to the user interface, the underlying data definitions, or the service layer.

With MCP servers running, your AI assistant doesn‚Äôt hallucinate blindly ‚Äî it knows your project structure.

Architecture in Action: Cline + SAP AI Core + MCP

Here‚Äôs how the pieces fit:

  1. Cline ‚ÄìYour coding agent inside the IDE, mediating prompts, code diffs, and project changes.
  2. SAP AI Core ‚Äì Hosts the foundation models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini) in a governed, enterprise-ready environment.
  3. MCP Servers ‚Äì mcp server expose structured context:
    • UI annotations, metadata, and manifest structure
    • Style guides and constraints
    • CDS entities and services

Workflow:

  • You prompt: ‚ÄúCreate a ListReport for SalesOrder with a status field.‚Äù
  • AI (via MCP) inspects CDS models and annotations.
  • AI generates the CDS extension, Fiori annotations, and manifest changes.
  • You review, test, and deploy.

This architecture transforms AI coding from a ‚Äútoy experiment‚Äù into a repeatable, enterprise-grade engineering practice.

How to Get SAP AI Core Credentials

  1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Navigate to AI Core: Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions ‚Üí AI Core
  3. Create Service Key:
    • Go to your AI Core service instance
    • Create a new service key
    • Copy the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, url, serviceurls)
  4. Configure Authentication URL: Usually follows pattern https://{subdomain}.authentication.{region}.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  5. Set Base URL: Typically https://api.ai.ml.hana.ondemand.com (check your service key for the exact URL)
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
SAP_AI_CORE_AUTH_URL=https://your-subdomain.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
SAP_AI_CORE_BASE_URL=https://base-ai-core-url
SAP_AI_CORE_RESOURCE_GROUP=your-resource-group

Refer to the screenshot below, which shows how we subscribed to the SAP AI Launchpad application to deploy our model according to the use case. We also created an SAP AI Core instance to obtain the necessary key details required for configuration in the Cline client.

Cline Configuration

  1. Install the Cline extension in VS Code
  2. Open Cline settings
  3. Configure these fields:
    • API Provider: Select "SAP AI Core"
    • Client ID: .clientid
    • Client Secret: .clientsecret
    • Base URL: .serviceurls.AI_API_URL
    • Auth URL: .url
    • AI Core Resource Group: Extract UUID from .appname (first part before the !)

       4. Test with a simple query to make sure it works

Add Server Configurations

To enable AI-assisted coding with full context, add the following server configurations to your cline_mcp_settings.json file. This configuration allows Cline to connect to the MCP servers that expose structured information about your project, including CDS models, Fiori metadata, manifest files, and coding style constraints. By providing these settings, you ensure that the AI assistant can:

  • Understand project structure: MCP servers give the AI visibility into your CDS entities, services, and UI annotations, allowing it to generate code that aligns with your existing models.
  • Follow enterprise standards: Style guides, naming conventions, and other constraints are passed through MCP servers, ensuring that generated code adheres to your organization‚Äôs best practices.
  • Generate context-aware code: Instead of generic snippets, the AI can create extensions, annotations, or manifests that fit seamlessly into your project.
  • Improve efficiency and reduce errors: By providing a structured context, the AI minimizes mismatches and hallucinations, letting developers focus on architecture, business logic, and user experience rather than repetitive boilerplate.

With the server configurations in place, Cline can interact with MCP servers in real time, making AI-assisted coding a safe, reliable, and enterprise-ready process.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "cds-mcp",
      "args": [],
      "env": {},
    }
  }
}

Set Guardrails with Cline Rules (How-To)

Purpose: Provide persistent, project-level guidance ‚Äî covering scope, coding style, documentation standards, and more ‚Äî that‚Äôs always active in your workspace.

Cline Rules act as a continuous, automated advisor for your development team. By defining guardrails, you ensure that AI-assisted coding adheres to enterprise standards and project-specific conventions. This prevents inconsistent implementations, reduces technical debt, and maintains code quality across the team.

  1. Create a Rule File
    1. In Cline‚Äôs Rules tab, click ‚Äú+‚Äù or use the command: /newrule.
    2. Save as a single file: .clinerules at the repo root, or use a folder-based setup .clinerules/ for multiple rules.
  2. Recommended Folder Structure
your-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .clinerules/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 01-project.md      
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 02-coding.md
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 03-documentation.md  
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/
  • Each file addresses a specific aspect of project guidance: project scope, coding standards, and documentation expectations.

Example Prompt Flow

You: "Initialise an empty SAP CAP application in this folder."
AI: The empty CAP application has been successfully initialised in the current folder

 

You: "Generate an entities sales and sales order items"
AI: The entities is successfully created.

Result: you stay focused on implementing business logic and refining the user experience, while the AI assistant handles all the scaffolding, boilerplate, and repetitive code generation.

Open the Cline application and start the conversation with the above commands ‚Äî this is where vibe coding truly comes alive, as your AI assistant (powered by MCP servers and SAP AI Core) begins generating context-aware code that you review, refine, and evolve into enterprise-ready solutions.

Once you select the Plan and submit the prompt, Cline (with MCP servers in the loop) interprets your intent, fetches the right CAP/Fiori context, and proposes structured code changes that you can review and refine into a production-ready solution.

You will now see a fully scaffolded CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application generated ‚Äî with entities, services, and annotations created automatically based on your prompt, thanks to the MCP servers providing structured context to the AI assistant.

Benefits & Caution

Benefits

  • Faster Prototyping and Scaffolding ‚Äì Quickly generate CAP entities, Fiori views, and annotations without manual boilerplate work.
  • Reduced Hallucinations ‚Äì Structured context from MCP servers ensures AI proposals are relevant and accurate.
  • Freed Mental Bandwidth ‚Äì Focus on UX, domain logic, and performance optimization, while AI handles repetitive scaffolding.
  • Aligned with SAP Standards & Governance ‚Äì Generated code respects enterprise best practices and architectural guidelines.

Caution

  • MCP Servers Are Evolving ‚Äì Always review AI-generated code before deployment.
  • Complex Business Logic Needs Oversight ‚Äì Human expertise is essential for transactional integrity, security, and edge-case handling.
  • Prompt Precision Matters ‚Äì Well-crafted prompts yield better, more reliable results.
  • Governance Remains Your Responsibility ‚Äì Testing, security, and compliance cannot be fully delegated to AI.

Conclusion

Vibe coding isn‚Äôt just about writing code faster ‚Äî it‚Äôs about reimagining how we build enterprise software. By combining AI assistants, SAP AI Core, and MCP servers, we provide AI the context it needs to act as a true development partner.

This approach lets developers move beyond boilerplate work and focus on what matters most: architecture, business logic, user experience, and innovation

Human expertise remains essential. Governance, compliance, performance tuning, and creativity stay firmly in the developer‚Äôs hands. But with vibe coding, tedious and repetitive tasks are no longer blockers ‚Äî they‚Äôre delegated.

As these patterns mature, this may be remembered as the moment enterprise development evolved from ‚Äúwriting code‚Äù to ‚Äúdesigning conversations.‚Äù The future of coding in SAP isn‚Äôt just AI-assisted ‚Äî it‚Äôs context-aware, collaborative, and human-centered.

entry.title: Re: Depreciation KEY in Chart of Depr. 3710 (NL) does not...
entry.content:
Hello @Pieter_ 

Thank you for your question.

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, depreciation keys are country-specific and are preconfigured within the delivered Chart of Depreciation (CoD).

Each company code is automatically associated with its respective country's CoD, and this assignment cannot be altered.

This clarifies the reason for the different behaviour observed with the LINE key.

In CoD 3710 Netherlands, LINE is provided with a Base Value of 24 Net book value and Depreciation to the day, so the calculation is based on NBV.

In CoD 2510 (Belgium), LINE is provided with a Base Value of 01, Which Represents the Acquisition value, meaning depreciation is computed based on the initial acquisition cost.

This difference is intentional, since SAP provides CoD content that complies with local statutory and accounting standards.

In the Public Cloud, customers are unable to copy, redefine, or modify depreciation keys themselves. If your legal requirement in the Netherlands dictates the use of the Belgian variant (base 01), the supported approach is to raise an SAP support incident or submit a request via the Customer Influence Portal for SAP to provide an additional depreciation key in CoD 3710.

SAP Documentation References

SAP Help ‚Äì Depreciation Keys in Asset Accounting (Public Cloud)

SAP Note 2723845 ‚Äì Depreciation keys in S/4HANA Cloud(U-user login required)

SAP KBA 3593674 ‚ÄìChanging the depreciation key for different types of unposted assets results in varying outcomes - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: Devtoberfest 2025 Contest Official Rules
entry.content:
@LuizSouza_L2D - I wish we could, but this determination is done by SAP legal.  Countries that are excluded are due to contest laws in that country that either explicitly exclude participation or that make it logistically impossible. Here's what I know specifically about Brazil:

In Brazil, what might look like a ‚Äúcontest‚Äù or giveaway in the U.S. often falls under ‚Äúprize promotion / commercial promotion‚Äù rules. That means registration, authorization, and oversight by their government. 

The promoter must file for permission with the ‚ÄúCommercial Promotion Control System‚Äù (or equivalent) 40 to 120 days before the campaign starts. If you fail to comply (no authorization, break rules, etc.), you could be fined up to 100% of the prize value and banned from running promotions for up to 2 years. Also, there are ‚Äúinspection fees‚Äù (basically regulatory fees) proportional to the prize value.

You almost certainly will need a Brazilian legal entity (or a partnership) to sponsor or own the promotion in Brazil so that the campaign can be ‚Äúauthorized‚Äù there. You‚Äôll need to submit your paperwork 1‚Äì4 months in advance (in many cases 40‚Äì120 days before launch). Your marketing copy must fully comply with Brazil‚Äôs stringent consumer protection and advertising laws (clear disclosures, no misleading claims, etc.). You‚Äôll need to pay inspection/regulatory fees and accept that penalty risk is high for noncompliance (including fines equal to the prize value or long bans). In practice, many international brands avoid including Brazil because of the hassle and risk. It‚Äôs not impossible ‚Äî but it demands careful legal structure, local partnerships, and a willingness to endure bureaucracy and regulatory oversight.

entry.title: Any API to get all users which would respond positively to a given AUTHORITY-CHECK?
entry.content:
Hi,

In the flexible workflow, I'm asked to implement the method RESPONSIBILITY_RULE of the BAdI RSM_BADI_STATIC_RULE, to return the agents who have a given authorization e.g., AUTHORITY-CHECK 'ZZZZZ' FOR USER user ID field1 FIELD value1 ID field2 FIELD value2, etc. The workflow task can then be processed by any of these agents.

For information, our authorization values contain wildcards (values *, CX3101*) or are fixed (CX32). No intervals.

Is there any official (released) API which does that, or do you have any other recommendation?

I have searched a little bit:

  • The only API authorization query I know, CL_AUTH_OBJECTS_TO_SQL (cf. ABAP Keyword documentation) is not relevant for this query. It transforms some authorizations of the current user into a WHERE clause to select the values from a given database table (to avoid selecting all the lines and then removing the forbidden values by LOOP AT + AUTHORITY-CHECK).
  • The function module SUSR_GET_PROFS_WITH_SPEC_OBJCT (followed by LOOP AT + AUTHORITY-CHECK) can do the job but is not released and is a little bit slow. Its logic is:
    • All accesses to the database tables is without buffer
    • Get all the authorizations corresponding to the authorization object (USR12)
    • LOOP AT the authorizations
      • Get the profiles corresponding to these authorizations (UST10S)
    • Get the subprofiles of these profiles via FOR ALL ENTRIES (UST10C)
    • Get all the users corresponding to these profiles and subprofiles via FOR ALL ENTRIES (UST04)
  • Reading directly the database tables above, with a join. I just did a test and it's faster (with HANA)

Thanks.

Sandra

PS: my system is S/4HANA On Premises, ABAP 7.58.

entry.title: Re: Timeline for enable Latest Experience of Performance...
entry.content:
Hi,

We had the same problem. Our solution (that is tested but not yet live).

Usually, form were launch in December in "prior year", in "Objective Setting" step. During the year the form moves, and due to our company often needing to compare performance with market data, we only close our PM forms in March of the following year. Meaning the form is open roughly 15 months.

Our solution:

  1. not use a form during Objective setting, and fully rely on Goal setting module.
  2. launch the forms in May as we open "Mid-year" review.
  3. Closing the forms would still by lie before in March. So new form would be open for "only" 11 months.

But this time we would have no forms active during April and May, allowing just enough time to launch new PM Form experience (and the AI stuff).

We have no fully tested this, and are preparing to launch the Goal Management late December.

Please keep up posted on how you develop your strategy,

BR,

Kris

entry.title: Re: Shipment cost: One truck, multiple stops
entry.content:
In LE‚ÄëTRA, the Shipment Document (created in VT01N/VT02N) represents the physical truck. You can assign multiple deliveries (even from different customers) to the same shipment. Each delivery becomes a stage/stop in the shipment, based on the route and stop sequence. If multiple deliveries go to the same Ship‚ÄëTo address, they are grouped into one stop (one stage). This way, the system reflects the real‚Äëlife situation: one truck, one drop, even if several deliveries are unloaded there.

Coming to Shipment Cost, configure the following:

  • Base Truck Charge - A flat fee per truck/shipment document.
  • Stop/Stage Surcharge - A condition type that charges per stop. The system counts the number of stages (unique Ship‚ÄëTo addresses) and applies the surcharge accordingly. Example: 2 stops = 2 √ó surcharge.
  • Pallet‚ÄëBased Charge - If pallet count is available (or approximated via weight/volume), you can configure a condition type to calculate cost per pallet. This ensures fair allocation when one customer‚Äôs delivery is much larger than another‚Äôs.


In customizing, you define how shipment costs are distributed to the underlying deliveries/items. Standard distribution rules include:

  • By gross weight
  • By net weight
  • By volume
  • By value
  • Or equally across deliveries

This ensures that the truck cost (base + stops + pallets) is split fairly across all deliveries on that truck.

Once the shipment cost document is calculated, you settle it to the appropriate FI/CO receiver:

  • Vendor (for freight invoice verification)
  • Cost center
  • Internal order, etc.

The distributed costs flow back into the deliveries and ultimately into billing/CO‚ÄëPA, so you can see the impact per customer.

entry.title: SAP ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx v1.4.0 released
entry.content:
On September 26, 2025, IBM has released version 1.4.0 of its ABAP¬Æ Software Development Kit (SDK) for IBM¬Æ watsonx‚Ñ¢ services. The watsonx.ai service can be used to train, validate, tune, and deploy foundation and machine learning models. The watsonx.ai Runtime is used to build, run and manage generative AI and machine learning applications with built-in performance and scalabilityThe ABAP SDK provides a class library that can be downloaded to SAP systems using abapGit and comes in two flavors:

  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP NetWeaver for the SAP Business Suite running on SAP NetWeaver 7.50 or above and for the SAP S/4HANA on-premises edition.
  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP BTP ABAP Environment for the SAP Business Technology Platform ABAP Environment.

Enhancements in this release include new watsonx.ai methods in the groups Prompt Sessions and Prompts. More information about the changes in version 1.4.0 can be found in the repositories in the migration document MIGRATION-V1.4.0.md.

Detailed information on how to setup and use the SDK can be found in the README.md files of the GitHub repositories. The README.md files also provide two comprehensive examples to show how the supported services can be used. An even more elaborated article about how use watsonx services with the ABAP SDK can be found in Joachim Rese's blog article How to Bring Generative AI to Your ABAP Program Using the ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx.

entry.title: Re: Error msg "Microsoft.Network/privateEndpoints is curr...
entry.content:
(auto-answering my own question, as I managed to get it working). I unfortunately misread the docs : at article https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/private-link-microsoft-azure.html , I naively took the resourceID of the private link, and not the resourceID of the final resource (my CosmosDB instance), because the doc says : 

Navigate to the Azure resource for which you want to find out the Resource ID, for example: Private Link Center > Private link services.

But if you simply grab the correct one from CosmosDB, then the string matches the ".../providers/Microsoft.DocumentDB/databaseAccounts..." format, that the BTP backend expects, and I got no error message anymore ü•≥

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Work Zone Security
entry.content:
Hi @ROHITGERA1,

unfortunately I'm not an export with CIS and Work Zone but I'll give it a try:

1. you can configure SSO with Microsoft Entra without User Provisioning (running CIS in proxy mode) or with user provisioning. In the second case, users are "copied" from Microsoft Entra to CIS (more specifically: Identity Directory Service).
If you need to provision users to Work Zone, you need a user source. So those users have to be available in one source. CIS is a likely candidate in a SAP scenario.

2. I don't know but potentially u could have multiple IPS scenarios setup where u provision users from multiple sources to a central user story like CIS (Identity Directory Service) and from there u provision the users to your target solutions?

3. Seems like the standard edition supports it as well: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/configure-integration-with-identity-provisioning-service

Best, Martin
